intro: Buglossa arvensis, commonly known as field bugloss, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open, disturbed habitats such as roadsides and meadows. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are clustered in dense, spike-like inflorescences. Buglossa arvensis is known for its ability to thrive in poor soils and its role in supporting pollinators.
